questions.question: Section 1245 property includes all of the following EXCEPT:

options.B: Office equipment
options.C: A commercial building

questions.explanation: Section 1245 property includes personal property (tangible and intangible) that is depreciable, such as machinery, equipment, and vehicles. Commercial buildings are real property subject to Section 1250 recapture rules, not Section 1245. Section 1245 requires full recapture of depreciation as ordinary income.
questions.tip: Section 1245 = personal property (full recapture). Section 1250 = real property (partial recapture).

questions.question: Which of the following qualifies as a Section 1231 asset?

options.B: Stock held for investment
options.C: Equipment used in a trade or business held more than one year

questions.explanation: Section 1231 assets include depreciable property and real property used in a trade or business and held for more than one year. Inventory is excluded (ordinary income), investment property is capital, and personal residence is not business property. Section 1231 provides favorable treatment: gains are long-term capital, losses are ordinary.
questions.tip: Section 1231 = business property held > 1 year. Best of both worlds: capital gains, ordinary losses.

questions.question: To qualify for long-term capital gain treatment, a capital asset must be held for:

options.B: At least 12 months
options.C: More than 12 months

questions.explanation: Long-term capital gain or loss treatment requires a holding period of MORE than one year. The holding period begins the day after acquisition and includes the date of sale. An asset held for exactly 12 months is still short-term; it must be held for at least one year plus one day.
questions.tip: MORE than 12 months = long-term. The day after purchase is day 1 of the holding period.

questions.question: For individual taxpayers, the maximum capital loss deduction against ordinary income in any year is:
questions.explanation: Individual taxpayers can deduct up to $3,000 ($1,500 if married filing separately) of net capital losses against ordinary income each year. Excess losses are carried forward indefinitely, retaining their character as short-term or long-term. Corporations cannot deduct capital losses against ordinary income.
questions.tip: $3,000 limit for individuals. Corporations = $0 against ordinary income; carryback 3 years, forward 5 years.

questions.question: Under Section 1031, like-kind exchanges now apply only to:

options.B: Real property used in business or held for investment
options.C: Personal property used in business

questions.explanation: After the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017, Section 1031 like-kind exchanges apply only to real property used in a trade or business or held for investment. Personal property, such as equipment or vehicles, no longer qualifies. Real property in the U.S. is like-kind to any other U.S. real property.
questions.tip: Post-TCJA: only real estate qualifies for 1031. Vehicles, equipment, and artwork no longer qualify.

questions.question: The installment method allows taxpayers to:

options.A: Defer all gain until the final payment
options.B: Recognize gain proportionally as payments are received
options.C: Convert ordinary income to capital gain

questions.explanation: The installment method under Section 453 allows taxpayers to recognize gain proportionally as payments are received, matching income recognition with cash collection. The gross profit percentage (gain/contract price) is applied to each payment. Depreciation recapture must be recognized in the year of sale.
questions.tip: Installment method: gain recognized as cash received. Gross profit % × each payment. Recapture accelerated to year of sale.

questions.question: Equipment with a cost of $50,000 and accumulated depreciation of $30,000 is sold for $45,000. The Section 1245 recapture is:
questions.explanation: Adjusted basis = $50,000 - $30,000 = $20,000. Total gain = $45,000 - $20,000 = $25,000. Section 1245 recaptures depreciation to the extent of gain. Since gain ($25,000) is less than total depreciation ($30,000), all $25,000 is recaptured as ordinary income.
questions.tip: 1245 recapture = lesser of (gain) or (depreciation taken). Full depreciation recaptured up to the gain amount.

questions.question: Unrecaptured Section 1250 gain on the sale of depreciable real property is taxed at a maximum rate of:
questions.explanation: Unrecaptured Section 1250 gain (straight-line depreciation on real property) is taxed at a maximum rate of 25%. This applies to the portion of gain attributable to depreciation deductions taken on the property. Any gain in excess of depreciation is taxed at regular capital gain rates.
questions.tip: 25% rate for depreciation recapture on real estate. Only applies if gain exceeds the unrecaptured amount.

questions.question: A taxpayer has a $20,000 Section 1231 gain and a $5,000 Section 1231 loss. The net result is:

options.B: $15,000 long-term capital gain
options.C: $20,000 long-term capital gain and $5,000 ordinary loss

questions.explanation: Net Section 1231 gains are treated as long-term capital gains unless the 5-year lookback rule applies. If the taxpayer had net Section 1231 losses in any of the prior 5 years that were deducted as ordinary losses, the current gain is recharacterized as ordinary income to the extent of those prior losses.
questions.tip: 1231 lookback: prior 5 years' ordinary losses must be 'recaptured' as ordinary income before capital gain treatment.

questions.question: In a like-kind exchange, the receipt of boot results in:

options.B: Recognition of gain to the extent of boot received
options.C: No gain recognition if boot is under 25% of value
options.D: Deferral of gain equal to the boot amount

questions.explanation: Boot is non-like-kind property (cash or other property) received in an exchange. Gain is recognized to the extent of boot received, but not in excess of the realized gain. Loss is never recognized in a like-kind exchange, even if boot is received.
questions.tip: Recognized gain = lesser of (realized gain) or (boot received). Losses are never recognized in 1031 exchanges.

questions.question: In a like-kind exchange where the taxpayer receives only like-kind property, the basis in the new property is:

options.A: Fair market value of property received
options.B: Adjusted basis of property given up
options.C: Average of FMV and adjusted basis
options.D: Original cost of property given up

questions.explanation: In a like-kind exchange with no boot, the basis of the property received equals the adjusted basis of the property given up. This substituted basis preserves the deferred gain or loss. If boot is received, basis is adjusted for recognized gain and boot received.
questions.tip: No boot: new basis = old basis (substituted). With boot: new basis = old basis + gain recognized - boot received.

questions.question: Property with a basis of $60,000 is sold for $100,000, with $25,000 down and the balance in equal annual installments over 3 years. The gross profit percentage is:
questions.explanation: Gross profit = Selling price - Adjusted basis = $100,000 - $60,000 = $40,000. Gross profit percentage = Gross profit / Contract price = $40,000 / $100,000 = 40%. Each payment received will include 40% gain recognition.
questions.tip: GP% = Gross profit / Contract price. Apply this percentage to each principal payment received.

questions.question: A father sells stock with a basis of $20,000 to his son for its fair market value of $15,000. The tax consequence to the father is:

options.B: $5,000 ordinary loss
options.C: No loss recognized

questions.explanation: Losses on sales between related parties are disallowed under Section 267. The father cannot recognize the $5,000 loss. However, if the son later sells the property at a gain, he can use the disallowed loss to offset that gain. Related parties include family members, controlled entities, and certain trusts.
questions.tip: Related party losses are disallowed but can offset the buyer's future gain. Losses disappear if buyer sells at a loss.

questions.question: An investor sells stock at a $10,000 loss and purchases substantially identical stock 25 days later. The tax treatment is:

options.B: $10,000 loss is permanently disallowed
options.C: $10,000 loss is disallowed but added to the basis of the new stock
options.D: Loss is deductible if held for 30 days

questions.explanation: The wash sale rule disallows a loss if substantially identical stock is purchased within 30 days before or after the sale. The disallowed loss is added to the basis of the replacement stock, effectively deferring (not eliminating) the loss. The holding period of the old stock tacks onto the new stock.
questions.tip: Wash sale = 30 days before or after. Loss disallowed but added to new stock's basis. Not a permanent loss.

questions.question: The 3.8% net investment income tax (NIIT) applies to:

options.B: Investment income of taxpayers with MAGI over $200,000/$250,000
options.C: Only dividend income
options.D: Investment income but not capital gains

questions.explanation: The NIIT is 3.8% of the lesser of net investment income or the excess of MAGI over threshold ($200,000 single, $250,000 MFJ). Net investment income includes interest, dividends, capital gains, rents, royalties, and passive income. Wages and self-employment income are excluded.
questions.tip: 3.8% NIIT: applies to investment income (including capital gains) when MAGI exceeds thresholds. Added on top of regular rates.

questions.question: A married couple filing jointly can exclude up to how much gain on the sale of their principal residence?
questions.explanation: Under Section 121, married couples filing jointly can exclude up to $500,000 of gain on the sale of their principal residence if both spouses meet the use test (2 of 5 years) and at least one meets the ownership test. Single taxpayers can exclude up to $250,000.
questions.tip: MFJ = $500,000 if both use test, one ownership test. Single/MFS = $250,000. Must be principal residence 2 of 5 years.

questions.question: For 2024, personal casualty losses are deductible only if:

options.B: The loss is from a federally declared disaster
options.C: The loss exceeds $100

questions.explanation: Under TCJA, personal casualty losses are deductible only if attributable to a federally declared disaster. The $100 per-casualty floor and 10% of AGI floor still apply. Non-disaster personal casualty losses can only offset personal casualty gains. Business casualty losses are still fully deductible.
questions.tip: Post-TCJA: personal casualty losses only from federally declared disasters. Still subject to $100 and 10% AGI floors.

questions.question: Under Section 1033, gain on an involuntary conversion is deferred if replacement property is acquired within:

options.A: 2 years from the end of the tax year in which the gain was realized
options.B: 2 years from the date of the conversion
options.C: 3 years from the date of the conversion

questions.explanation: The replacement period for involuntary conversions is 2 years from the close of the first tax year in which any gain is realized. For condemned real property held for business or investment, the period is 3 years. The replacement property must be similar or related in service or use.
questions.tip: 2 years from end of year gain realized (not from conversion date). Real property condemnation = 3 years.

questions.question: In a deferred like-kind exchange, the replacement property must be identified within:

options.B: 45 days and received within 180 days
options.C: 60 days and received within 180 days
options.D: 90 days and received within one year

questions.explanation: In a deferred (Starker) exchange, the replacement property must be identified within 45 days and received within 180 days (or the due date of the return, including extensions, if earlier). These deadlines are strict and cannot be extended except in presidentially declared disasters.
questions.tip: 45 days to identify, 180 days to close. Both periods start from the transfer of relinquished property. No extensions!

questions.question: Passive activity losses can be deducted against:

options.B: Only passive income
options.C: Portfolio income and passive income

questions.explanation: Passive activity losses can only offset passive activity income under Section 469. They cannot offset active income (wages, self-employment) or portfolio income (interest, dividends, capital gains). Suspended losses carry forward and are released when the activity is disposed of in a fully taxable transaction.
questions.tip: Passive losses only offset passive income. Suspended losses released on complete taxable disposition.

questions.question: A taxpayer's at-risk amount includes all of the following EXCEPT:

options.B: Adjusted basis of property contributed
options.C: Nonrecourse financing not secured by real property
options.D: Qualified nonrecourse financing for real estate

questions.explanation: At-risk amount includes cash and adjusted basis of property contributed, amounts borrowed for which the taxpayer is personally liable (recourse), and qualified nonrecourse financing for real estate. General nonrecourse debt (where the taxpayer has no personal liability) is not included except for real estate.
questions.tip: At-risk = cash + basis + recourse debt + qualified nonrecourse RE financing. General nonrecourse debt excluded.

questions.question: If a taxpayer sells property to a related party on the installment method and the related party resells within 2 years:

options.A: No additional gain is recognized by either party
options.B: The original seller must recognize gain as if the installment sale was for cash
options.C: Only the related party recognizes gain on the resale
options.D: Both parties share the gain recognition equally

questions.explanation: When a related party buyer resells property within 2 years, the original seller must recognize gain as if the original sale was for cash (to the extent of the resale proceeds). This rule prevents using installment sales to related parties as a device to defer gain while still getting cash out of the property.
questions.tip: Related party resale within 2 years accelerates the original seller's gain. Prevents installment sale abuse.

questions.question: In a like-kind exchange involving Section 1245 property, depreciation recapture is:

options.A: Completely deferred along with other gain
options.B: Recognized only to the extent of boot received
options.C: Recognized in full regardless of exchange treatment

questions.explanation: In a like-kind exchange, Section 1245 recapture is triggered only to the extent of boot received or recognized gain. If the exchange is boot-free, no recapture is recognized. The recapture potential carries over to the replacement property, to be recognized on its eventual taxable disposition.
questions.tip: 1245 recapture in 1031 = to extent of boot/gain recognized. Recapture potential transfers to new property.

questions.question: Which of the following would satisfy the material participation test for an activity?

options.A: 100 hours of participation during the year
options.B: More than 100 hours if no one else participated more
options.C: Any participation in a management role
options.D: 500 hours of participation during the year

questions.explanation: Material participation requires meeting one of seven tests. The most common is participating for more than 500 hours during the year. The 100-hour test (option B) requires that no one else participated more. Limited partners face stricter rules. Material participation converts passive income/loss to nonpassive.
questions.tip: 500 hours = automatic material participation. Other tests exist but 500 hours is the most straightforward.

questions.question: Long-term capital gains from the sale of collectibles are taxed at a maximum rate of:
questions.explanation: Collectibles (art, antiques, gems, stamps, coins, precious metals) are subject to a maximum long-term capital gain rate of 28%, higher than the regular 15%/20% rates. Short-term gains on collectibles are taxed at ordinary rates. The 3.8% NIIT may also apply.
questions.tip: Collectibles max rate = 28%. Unrecaptured 1250 = 25%. Regular LTCG = 0/15/20%. Know the special rates!

questions.question: A real estate professional can treat rental real estate as nonpassive if:

options.A: They own more than 10% of any rental property
options.B: More than 50% of personal services and more than 750 hours are in real estate trades
options.C: They have any real estate license

questions.explanation: To qualify as a real estate professional: (1) more than 50% of personal services during the year must be in real property trades or businesses, and (2) more than 750 hours must be spent in those activities. Additionally, the taxpayer must materially participate in each rental activity (or elect to group them).
questions.tip: RE professional: 50% of services + 750 hours + material participation in each rental. Spouse hours don't count for the 750.

questions.question: Taxpayer exchanges property worth $500,000 with a $200,000 mortgage for property worth $400,000 with a $100,000 mortgage. The net mortgage relief treated as boot is:
questions.explanation: Mortgage relief is treated as boot received. Mortgage assumed is treated as boot given. Net mortgage boot = Mortgage relieved - Mortgage assumed = $200,000 - $100,000 = $100,000 net boot received. Cash boot can offset mortgage boot, but the taxpayer must also account for the FMV difference.
questions.tip: Net mortgage relief = boot received. Netting is only between mortgages, not with cash. Both directions matter.

questions.question: A taxpayer had a $15,000 net Section 1231 loss in Year 1. In Year 4, the taxpayer has a $25,000 net Section 1231 gain. The tax treatment in Year 4 is:

options.B: $10,000 long-term capital gain and $15,000 ordinary income
options.C: $15,000 long-term capital gain and $10,000 ordinary income

questions.explanation: The 5-year lookback rule requires that net Section 1231 gains be recharacterized as ordinary income to the extent of unrecaptured Section 1231 losses from the prior 5 years. The Year 1 loss of $15,000 is within the lookback period, so $15,000 of the Year 4 gain is ordinary income. The remaining $10,000 is LTCG.
questions.tip: Lookback: prior 5 years' 1231 losses recaptured first. What was deducted as ordinary must come back as ordinary.

questions.question: Gain from the sale of qualified small business stock (QSBS) held more than 5 years may be:

options.B: 50% excluded from income
options.C: 100% excluded from income (for stock acquired after 2010)

questions.explanation: For QSBS acquired after September 27, 2010, 100% of the gain may be excluded from federal income tax (up to the greater of $10 million or 10 times the taxpayer's basis). The stock must be in a C corporation with gross assets under $50 million, acquired at original issuance, and held more than 5 years.
questions.tip: QSBS post-2010 = 100% exclusion. Pre-2010 = 50% or 75%. Requirements: C corp, <$50M assets, original issue, 5+ years.

questions.question: A taxpayer who invests capital gains in a Qualified Opportunity Zone fund can:

options.B: Defer recognition until the earlier of sale or December 31, 2026
options.C: Convert ordinary income to capital gain
options.D: Claim an immediate deduction for the investment

questions.explanation: Investing capital gains in a QOZ fund defers recognition of the original gain until the earlier of the investment's sale or December 31, 2026. If held 10+ years, any appreciation in the QOZ investment may be permanently excluded. The original stepped-up basis benefits for 5/7 year holdings expired for investments after 2019.
questions.tip: QOZ: defer gain until sale or 12/31/2026. 10+ years = exclude appreciation on QOZ investment (not original gain).

questions.question: Section 1250 recapture at ordinary income rates applies to:

options.A: All depreciation taken on real property
options.B: Depreciation in excess of straight-line for pre-1987 real property
options.C: Any gain on sale of depreciable real property
options.D: Depreciation on property held less than one year

questions.explanation: Section 1250 recaptures as ordinary income only 'additional depreciation'—the excess of accelerated depreciation over straight-line. Since post-1986 real property must use straight-line depreciation, there is no additional depreciation to recapture. The 25% unrecaptured Section 1250 gain rule applies to straight-line depreciation.
questions.tip: 1250 ordinary recapture: only excess over straight-line (rare post-1986). Straight-line depreciation = 25% max rate.

questions.question: The $25,000 rental real estate loss allowance is:

options.A: Available to all rental property owners
options.B: Available to active participants with AGI under $150,000
options.C: Reduced by 50% of AGI in excess of $100,000
options.D: Available only to real estate professionals

questions.explanation: The $25,000 allowance is available to active participants (not just material participants) in rental real estate. It phases out by 50 cents for each dollar of AGI over $100,000, completely eliminated at $150,000 AGI. Active participation requires significant participation in management decisions.
questions.tip: $25,000 rental loss allowance: active participant, phaseout $100K-$150K AGI. Married filing separately = generally $0.

questions.question: Section 1244 small business stock allows a loss to be treated as:

options.A: Long-term capital loss regardless of holding period
options.B: Ordinary loss up to $50,000 ($100,000 if married filing jointly)
options.C: Deferred loss until future capital gains
options.D: Carryback loss against prior year capital gains

questions.explanation: Section 1244 allows individual taxpayers to treat losses on qualifying small business stock as ordinary losses (not capital) up to $50,000 per year ($100,000 MFJ). The stock must be issued by a domestic small business corporation for money or property. This provides greater deductibility than capital loss treatment.
questions.tip: Section 1244: ordinary loss treatment on SBC stock. $50K single, $100K MFJ. Losses in excess = capital.

questions.question: A taxpayer who sells their principal residence after owning and using it for only 15 months due to a job relocation may:

options.A: Exclude no gain because requirements weren't met
options.B: Exclude a prorated portion of the maximum exclusion
options.C: Exclude all gain up to the regular maximum

questions.explanation: When the 2-of-5-year requirement isn't met due to employment change, health, or unforeseen circumstances, a partial exclusion is available. The exclusion is prorated: (months lived in / 24) × maximum exclusion. For 15 months: 15/24 × $250,000 = $156,250 (single) or × $500,000 = $312,500 (MFJ).
questions.tip: Partial exclusion for job, health, or unforeseen circumstances. Pro rata based on months used ÷ 24 months.

questions.question: When Section 1245 property is sold on the installment method, the depreciation recapture is:

options.B: Recognized in full in the year of sale
options.C: Deferred until the final payment
options.D: Excluded from the installment method calculation

questions.explanation: Depreciation recapture under Section 1245 and Section 1250 is recognized in full in the year of sale, regardless of installment method treatment. The recapture amount increases basis for purposes of computing the remaining gain that can be deferred. Only the Section 1231 gain portion qualifies for installment treatment.
questions.tip: Recapture is accelerated to year of sale in installment sales. Cannot defer ordinary recapture income.
